{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2015}} {{Use British English|date=July 2015}} {{Infobox military person | name = Roger Henry Gartside Neville | image = | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1895|3|8}} | death_date = May {{Death year and age|1986|1895}} | birth_place = [[St Pancras, London|St. Pancras]], [[London]], [[England]] | death_place = [[Uckfield]], [[Surrey]], England | placeofburial_label = | placeofburial = | placeofburial_coordinates = | nickname = | branch = British Army
Royal Air Force | serviceyears = 1915–c.1946 | rank = Group Captain | unit = [[Duke of Cornwall's Light Infantry]]
[[No. 21 Squadron RAF|No. 21 Squadron RFC]]
[[No. 23 Squadron RAF|No. 23 Squadron RFC]] | commands = [[No. 29 Squadron RAF]]
[[No. 60 Squadron RAF]] | battles = World War I
{{*}}[[Western Front (World War I)|Western Front]]
World War II | awards = [[Military Cross]]
[[Order of the British Empire]] | spouse = {{marriage|Marion A. Chorlton|1918|1942}}
{{marriage|Joyce E. Oulton|1943}} | relations = [[Henry Gartside Neville]] (grandfather) | laterwork = }} Group Captain '''Roger Henry Gartside Neville''', {{post-nominals|country=GBR|size=100%|OBE|MC|sep=yes}} (8 March 1895 – May 1986) was a British [[World War I]] [[flying ace]] credited with five aerial victories.{{cite web |url=http://www.theaerodrome.com/aces/england/neville.php |title=Roger Henry Gartside Neville |work=The Aerodrome |year=2015 |accessdate=9 July 2015}} He remained in the RAF post war serving as a squadron commander, and then as a staff officer, until after the end of the World War II. ==Biography== ===Family background=== Roger Neville was born in [[St. Pancras, London]], the son of John Ernest Gartside Neville, a [[stockbroker]], and his wife Jane (née Gartside). His grandfather was the actor and theatrical manager [[Henry Gartside Neville]].{{cite journal |url=http://barrycollinsfamily.com/getperson.php?personID=I1120&tree=Tree-1 |title=Roger Henry Gartside Neville |first=Darrin |last=Lythgoe |work=Genealogy of the Collins family of Heyford, Sheffield & Oldham |year=2015 |accessdate=9 July 2015}} ===First World War=== After attending the [[Royal Military College, Sandhurst]], as a "gentlemen cadet", Neville was commissioned as a second lieutenant in the [[Duke of Cornwall's Light Infantry]] on 14 July 1915.{{London Gazette |date=13 July 1915 |issue=29228 |startpage=6840 |endpage=6841 |nolink=yes}} He was soon seconded to the [[Royal Flying Corps]], and appointed a flying officer on 18 November.{{London Gazette |date=14 December 1915 |issue=29402 |startpage=12443 |nolink=yes}} He joined No. 21 Squadron in early 1916, to fly a [[Royal Aircraft Factory B.E.12]] single-seat bomber.Shores ''et.al.'' (1990), p.290. On 21 July 1916 he was appointed a [[flight commander]] with the temporary rank of captain.{{London Gazette |date=8 August 1916 |supp=yes |issue=29699 |startpage=7860 |nolink=yes}} Neville scored his first aerial victory on 14 September 1916, destroying a German [[LVG]] two-seater reconnaissance aircraft south-west of [[Vélu]]. Eight days later, he was wounded in action. In November he was awarded the Military Cross. His citation read: :Second Lieutenant (Temporary Captain) Roger Henry Gartside Neville, Duke of Cornwall's Light Infantry and Royal Flying Corps. ::"For conspicuous skill and gallantry. He is a fine leader of patrol work, and has done much to keep enemy machines away from our lines. On one occasion, flying in a rainstorm, after nearly colliding with an enemy machines he pursued it and brought it down half a mile from an enemy aerodome."{{London Gazette |date=14 November 1916 |supp=yes |issue=29824 |startpage=11062 |nolink=yes}} Neville returned to duty, assigned to No. 23 Squadron, to fly a [[Spad VII]] single-seat fighter.{{cite web |url=http://www.theaerodrome.com/services/gbritain/rfc/23.php |title=No. 23 Squadron |work=The Aerodrome |year=2015 |accessdate=9 July 2015}} He received a regimental promotion, to lieutenant in the [[Duke of Cornwall's Light Infantry|DCLI]] on 1 July 1917.{{London Gazette |date=21 December 1917 |supp=yes |issue=30444 |startpage=13462 |nolink=yes}} He gained a double aerial victory on 6 July 1917, destroying and driving down out of control two [[Albatros D.V]]s over [[Tourcoing]], and on 11 July he drove down another D.V out of control over [[Westrozebeke]]. His fifth and final victory came on 27 July, when he and Second Lieutenant [[Frederick J. Gibbs]] shared in the destruction of an Aviatik C over Kezelberg. ===Post war career=== Neville remained seconded to the RAF after the end of the war, and his period of service was extended for two years on 1 August 1919,{{London Gazette |date=27 April 1920 |issue=31879 |startpage=4850 |nolink=yes}} again on 1 August 1921,{{London Gazette |date=14 October 1921 |issue=32487 |startpage=8103 |nolink=yes}} and for a third time on 1 August 1923, by which time he held the rank of [[flight lieutenant]].{{cite journal |url= http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1923/1923%20-%200485.html |title=Royal Air Force: Appointments |issue=763 |volume=XV |page=485 |journal=[[Flight International|Flight]] |date=9 August 1923 |accessdate=9 July 2015}} Neville was eventually granted a permanent commission in the RAF on 5 March 1924,{{London Gazette |date=4 March 1924 |issue=32915 |startpage=1931 |nolink=yes}} and was promoted to squadron leader on 1 July.{{London Gazette |date=1 July 1924 |issue=32952 |startpage=5088 |endpage=5089 |nolink=yes}} On 12 August he was appointed Commanding Officer of [[No. 29 Squadron RAF]], based at [[RAF Duxford]],{{cite journal |url= http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1924/1924%20-%200519.html |title=Royal Air Force: Appointments |issue=816 |volume=XVI |page=519 |journal=[[Flight International|Flight]] |date=14 August 1924 |accessdate=9 July 2015}} and the following year lead his squadron in the 1925 Air Defence Manoeuvres, as part of the defending forces of "Westland" against the attackers from "Eastland".{{cite journal |url= http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1927/1927%20-%200574.html |first=F.A. de V. |last=Robertson |title=Air Defence Manoeuvres |issue=970 |volume=XIX |page=526 |journal=[[Flight International|Flight]] |date=28 July 1927 |accessdate=9 July 2015}} On 3 July 1926 he took part in an exhibition of close formation flying by nine aircraft from six fighter squadrons — 54 in all — as part of the seventh RAF Aerial Pageant at [[Hendon Aerodrome]], at which time No. 29 Squadron were flying [[Gloster Grebe]]s.{{cite journal |url=http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1926/1926%20-%200467.html |title=Seventh RAF Aerial Pageant |first=F.A. de V. |last=Robertson |issue=915 |volume=XVIII |page=405 |journal=[[Flight International|Flight]] |date=8 July 1926 |accessdate=9 July 2015}} On 2 September 1927 he took command of [[No. 60 Squadron RAF]], based in India.{{cite journal |url=http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1927/1927%20-%200711.html |title=Royal Air Force: Appointments |issue=977 |volume=XIX |page=657 |journal=[[Flight International|Flight]] |date=15 September 1927 |accessdate=9 July 2015}} On 26 June 1931 he was made an [[Officer of the Order of the British Empire]] (Military Division) "for valuable services in connection with the operations on the [[North-West Frontier Province (1901–55)|North-West Frontier of India]] between 23 April and 12 September 1930".{{London Gazette |date=26 June 1931 |issue=33729 |startpage=4152 |nolink=yes}} On 1 July 1932 he was promoted to wing commander,{{cite journal |url= http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1932/1932%20-%200687.html |title=Royal Air Force: Promotions |issue=1228 |volume=XXIV |page=639 |journal=[[Flight International|Flight]] |date=8 July 1932 |accessdate=8 July 2015}} and on 19 July took command of the RAF School of Photography at [[Farnborough Airport|South Farnborough]].{{cite journal |url=http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1932/1932%20-%200797.html |title=Royal Air Force: Appointments |issue=1232 |volume=XXIV |page=741 |journal=[[Flight International|Flight]] |date=5 August 1932 |accessdate=9 July 2015}} He then served as Station Commander of [[RAF North Weald]] until 14 December 1933, when he was appointed a staff officer at the Headquarters of the Central Area, [[Air Defence of Great Britain]], at [[RAF Abingdon]].{{cite journal |url=http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1933/1933%20-%201341.html |title=Royal Air Force: Appointments |issue=1305 |volume=XXV |page=1319 |journal=[[Flight International|Flight]] |date=28 December 1933 |accessdate=8 July 2015}} On 27 August 1936 he was posted to the Headquarters of the Armament Group at [[RAF Eastchurch]].{{cite journal |url= http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1936/1936%20-%202488.html |title=Royal Air Force: Appointments |issue=1446 |volume=XXX |page=279 |journal=[[Flight International|Flight]] |date=10 September 1936 |accessdate=9 July 2015}} Neville was promoted to group captain on 1 July 1937.{{London Gazette |date=2 July 1937 |issue=34414 |startpage=4253 |nolink=yes}} Neville served in the RAF throughout the Second World War, receiving a [[mention in despatches]] on 1 January 1946.{{London Gazette |date=28 December 1945 |issue=37407 |startpage=89 |nolink=yes}} ==Personal life== Neville married Marion Aldyth Chorlton (1899–1942), of [[Prestwich]], on 2 April 1918.{{cite journal |url=http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1918/1918%20-%200411.html |title=Personals: Married |issue=485 |volume=X |page=409 |journal=[[Flight International|Flight]] |date=11 April 1918 |accessdate=8 July 2015}} They had one son, Christopher Roger Gartside Neville (1924–1998), who joined the RAF in 1944, and served until 1979, retiring with the rank of [[Air Commodore]].{{cite web |url= http://www.rafweb.org/Biographies/Neville_CRG.htm |title=C. R. G. Neville |first=M. B. |last=Barrass |work=Air of Authority - A History of RAF Organisation |year=2015 |accessdate=9 July 2015}} After his first wife's death he married Joyce E. Oulton at [[Hove]], Sussex, in December 1943. ==References== ;Notes {{reflist|30em}} ;Bibliography * {{cite book |first1=Christopher F. |last1=Shores |first2=Norman |last2=Franks |authorlink2=Norman Franks |first3=Russell F. |last3=Guest |title=Above the Trenches: a Complete Record of the Fighter Aces and Units of the British Empire Air Forces 1915–1920 |location=London, UK |publisher=Grub Street |year=1990 |isbn=978-0-948817-19-9 |lastauthoramp=yes}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Neville, Roger}} [[Category:1895 births]] [[Category:1986 deaths]] [[Category:People from St Pancras, London]] [[Category:Graduates of the Royal Military College, Sandhurst]] [[Category:Duke of Cornwall's Light Infantry officers]] [[Category:Royal Flying Corps officers]] [[Category:Royal Air Force officers]] [[Category:British World War I flying aces]] [[Category:Recipients of the Military Cross]] [[Category:Officers of the Order of the British Empire]]
